title-group.article-title: Computerized Adaptive Testing Using a Class of High-Order Item Response Theory Models

article-meta.aff: 1Taipei Municipal University of Education, Taipei, Taiwan
3The Hong Kong Institute of Education, Hong Kong

author-notes.corresp: Wen-Chung Wang, Department of Psychological Studies, The Hong Kong Institute of Education, 10 Lo Ping Rd., Tai Po, New Territories, Hong Kong Email: wcwang@ied.edu.hk

abstract.p: In the human sciences, a common assumption is that latent traits have a hierarchical structure. Higher order item response theory models have been developed to account for this hierarchy. In this study, computerized adaptive testing (CAT) algorithms based on these kinds of models were implemented, and their performance under a variety of situations was examined using simulations. The results showed that the CAT algorithms were very effective. The progressive method for item selection, the Sympson and Hetter method with online and freeze procedure for item exposure control, and the multinomial model for content balancing can simultaneously maintain good measurement precision, item exposure control, content balance, test security, and pool usage.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Second order or higher order factor analysis has been widely used in the social sciences because many latent traits have a hierarchical structure (Matin & Adkins, 1954; Thurstone, 1944). For example, cognitive abilities can be classified into three strata (Carroll, 1993): Stratum I, which consists of narrow abilities; Stratum II, which consists of broad abilities; and Stratum III, which is Spearman’s general ability. In an empirical study of the French version of the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale, Fourth Edition, a confirmatory third-order factor analysis showed that the factor loadings of the general ability on the broad abilities were fairly high, ranging from .71 to .91, and those of the broad abilities on the narrow abilities ranged from .63 to .87 (Golay & Lecerf, 2011). Personality, as measured by the Revised Neuroticism-Extraversion-Openness (NEO) Personality Inventory (Costa & McCrae, 1992), is another example of hierarchical latent traits. It is composed of five broad factors, each with six domains. Furthermore, the broad factors of neuroticism, agreeableness, and conscientiousness can be grouped into the third-order latent trait of stability, and the broad factors of openness and extraversion into another third-order latent trait of plasticity. The factor loadings of stability were between .56 and .65, and those of plasticity were between .95 and .29 for a sample of 245 college students (DeYoung, Peterson, & Higgins, 2002).

The latent traits measured by the Test of English as a Foreign Language are hierarchical, in which reading, listening, speaking, and writing are the first-order latent traits, and language proficiency is the second-order latent trait (Sawaki, Sticker, & Andreas, 2009). Another example in educational test batteries is the Programme for International Student Assessment, in which multiple domains (e.g., quantity, space and shape, change and relationship, and uncertainty) are measured in a subject (e.g., mathematics), and multiple subjects (e.g., mathematics, reading, and science) constitute a general concept of essential knowledge and skills. The domains, subjects, and general concepts can be viewed as the first-, second-, and third-order latent traits, respectively.

Conventionally, higher order factor analyses are linear models in that the relationship between the indicators and the factors is linear. When the indicators are categorical item responses, by definition, the relationship cannot be linear. Actually, higher order factor analysis can be adapted for categorical item responses through the incorporation of item response theory (IRT).

Most IRT models are unidimensional in that a single latent trait (dimension) is assumed to account for all of the common variance among the item responses. Unidimensional IRT models are not appropriate for multidimensional data. A test may consist of multiple subtests, and each subtest measures a distinct latent trait, or a test battery may consist of multiple tests, and each test measures a distinct latent trait. This is referred to as between-item multidimensional, because every item measures a single latent trait and different items may measure different latent traits. In contrast, when a test consists of items that measure two or more dimensions simultaneously, the test is within-item multidimensional (Adams, Wilson, & Wang, 1997). Unidimensional IRT models become inefficient for between-item multidimensional tests because the correlation among the latent traits cannot be used. Multidimensional IRT has been adopted to use the correlation to improve the measurement efficiency for individual subscales (Wang, Chen, & Cheng, 2004; Yao & Boughton, 2007).

Multidimensional IRT, although efficient for tests measuring multiple latent traits, is not applicable to hierarchical latent traits because the hierarchy is not considered. If multidimensional IRT is fit to data with a hierarchical structure of latent traits, the person measures of the first-order latent traits can be estimated directly, but those of the second-order or higher order latent traits cannot. This limitation is serious when, in practice, both of the person measures in the first-order latent traits and the higher order latent traits are to be reported. For example, the first-order latent traits can be used as a formative assessment for diagnostic purposes, and the higher order latent traits can provide overall performance for a summative assessment. Therefore, IRT models that can take both multidimensionality and hierarchy into consideration are needed.

There have been some developments in the integration of higher order factor analysis and IRT in recent years. Sheng and Wikle (2008), de la Torre and Song (2009), and de la Torre and Hong (2010) developed second-order IRT models to account for the first- and second-order latent traits simultaneously. Through simulation and empirical research, they found that when data responses with a hierarchical latent trait structure were analyzed with the hierarchical and the conventional unidimensional IRT models, respectively, the difference between the two methods in the person measures of the second-order latent traits became smaller as the correlations of the first-order latent traits increased, whereas the unidimensional IRT model always underestimated the posterior variance of the second-order latent trait measures.

The previously-mentioned second-order IRT models focus on dichotomous items and the three-parameter logistic model (3PLM; Birnbaum, 1968). Huang, Wang, and Chen (2010) proposed a general class of higher order IRT models for hierarchical latent traits (denoted as HIRT), which can both accommodate many existing IRT models for dichotomous or polytomous items and allow users to specify their own customized IRT models in the first order. Due to HIRT’s high dimensionality, they used Markov chain Monte Carlo methods to estimate the parameters and found that the parameters were recovered fairly well by using the freeware WinBUGS (Spiegelhalter, Thomas, & Best, 2003), with the root mean square errors generally around the second decimal place for the 1-parameter logistic model (1PLM) and 2-parameter logistic model (2PLM) and slightly larger for the 3-parameter logistic model (3PLM) (Birnbaum, 1968; Rasch, 1960).

Made possible by innovations in IRT and information technology in recent decades, computerized adaptive testing (CAT) has been widely implemented in educational and psychological measurement. A major advantage of CAT over nonadaptive testing (e.g., paper-and-pencil testing) is that CAT can reach the same degree of precision in the person measures as nonadaptive testing, but with fewer items. When multiple latent traits are estimated, CAT algorithms based on unidimensional IRT models are no longer efficient because the relationship between the latent traits is not taken into account. Consequently, CAT algorithms based on multidimensional IRT models (referred to as multidimensional computerized adaptive testing [MCAT]) were developed, and these were found to be more efficient than those based on the unidimensional IRT models (Li & Schafer, 2005; Mulder & van der Linden, 2009; Segall, 1996; Wang & Chen, 2004).

Given that HIRT is useful for hierarchical latent traits and their parameters can be estimated accurately, the next step would be to develop CAT algorithms to facilitate HIRT’s applicability, which is the major purpose of the present study. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, the existing CAT algorithms were developed for nonhierarchical IRT models, and no CAT algorithms have been developed specifically for HIRT. It is thus of great importance to develop CAT algorithms under HIRT, so that the person measures of the first- and second-order latent traits can be obtained simultaneously. In implementing CAT, practical constraints, such as item exposure control and content balance, often need to be considered, especially for high-stakes examinations. In addition, the implementation of different item-selection methods and the comparison of their efficiency are highly valuable. All of these issues are investigated in this study.

HIRT’s dimensionality is confirmatory. That is, which item measures which latent trait and which lower order latent traits can be grouped into a higher order latent trait are specified by the users according to some theories, rather than explored from the data. Note that the item response function in the first order can be very flexible. For example, in practice, a latent trait may be measured by dichotomous items only, polytomous items only, or a combination of the two. The WinBUGS freeware (Spiegelhalter et al., 2003) can easily accommodate this complexity, because each item can have its own item response function.

sec.title: CAT Algorithms Using HIRT
sec.p: HIRT is multidimensional because there are multiple random-effect latent variables, including one θ(2) and several ε(1) variables. Although testlet response models (Wainer, Bradlow, & Wang, 2007) can be viewed as special cases of HIRT, in which each first-order test is viewed as a testlet and the linear regression coefficient βs (Equation 1) are all set at unity (Sheng & Wikle, 2008), item-selection methods that were developed under testlet response models (Glas, Wainer, & Bradlow, 2000; Mulder & van der Linden, 2009; Murphy, Dodd, & Vaughn, 2010) are not applicable to HIRT. In the CAT algorithms for testlet response models, the specific latent trait for each testlet is treated as a nuisance variable and is not considered in the item-selection procedure. In the CAT algorithms for HIRT, in contrast, both the first-order and second-order latent traits are important and should be considered. The authors thus adopted the procedures in MCAT (Segall, 1996, 2004) for HIRT item selection.

In developing the HIRT-based CAT, the authors made references to the CAT algorithms used in testlet response theory models and multidimensional IRT models. The adaptation of these algorithms to HIRT, although not completely innovative, deserves special attention because of the technical complexity. The HIRT-based CAT algorithms differ from those of testlet response theory models (testlet-based CAT) in two important ways. First, the HIRT-based CAT is more general because HIRT encompasses testlet response theory models as special cases, so that the HIRT-based CAT can be adapted for testlet response theory models, but the testlet-based CAT cannot be adapted for HIRT. Second, the testlet-based CAT treats the testlet effect as a nuisance (due to the model assumption) and does not consider the testlet effect in item selection or ability estimation, whereas the HIRT-based CAT treats the first-order residuals as important factors and considers their effect in item selection and ability estimation, so that the person measures on the first- and second-order latent traits can be more precisely estimated.

sec.title: Item-Selection Methods and Practical Constraints
sec.p:
The most commonly used item-selection method is based on the FI information criterion. Using this criterion, an item is selected because it provides the maximum amount of information about a given provisional ability estimate
θ
^
. At the early stages of CAT, the provisional estimate may not be very close to the true level of the latent trait θ, so the FI method may not be very efficient, and some items may be overexposed. Several item-selection rules were proposed to resolve this problem, including the FI interval information (Veerkamp & Berger, 1997), FI with a posterior distribution (van der Linden, 1998), the Kullback–Leibler information (Chang & Ying, 1996), and the Kullback–Leibler information with a posterior distribution (Chang & Ying, 1996). It was found that for dichotomous items following 3PLM, these four alternative methods performed marginally better than the FI method during the early stages of CAT for very low levels of latent traits. For tests with more than 10 items, there appeared to be no advantage in precision for any of the selection rules (Chen, Ankenmann, & Chang, 2000). When content balancing and item exposure control are imposed, FI with a posterior distribution method and the Kullback–Leibler information with a posterior distribution method perform similarly to the FI method (Chen & Ankenmann, 2004).

Regarding CAT under multidimensional IRT models—including HIRT—the justification for using these alternative item-selection methods is even weaker because, compared with the FI method, they offer little gain in measurement precision and are more difficult to implement because of intensive numerical integration. Thus, the authors adopted two flexible and simple procedures that incorporate a random element into item selection: the progressive (PG) method (Barrada, Olea, Ponsoda, & Abad, 2008) and the proportional (PP) method (Barrada et al., 2008). In this study, the FI, PG, and PP methods were implemented for item selection.

Both the PG and PP methods consider the accuracy issue in the provisional estimates during the early stage of CAT. However, they may not adequately control item exposure, test overlap, and content balance because of the lack of direct control procedures. To resolve this problem, the Sympson and Hetter method with the online and freeze (SHOF) method (Chen, Lei, & Liao, 2008), and the multinomial model (MM) for content balancing (Chen, Ankenmann, & Spray, 2003) were adopted in this study. Unlike the traditional Sympson and Hetter method, the SHOF method does not require time-consuming simulation to develop the item exposure control parameters prior to the operational use of CAT. Let the maximum item exposure rate be denoted as rmax and the initial item exposure parameter Pi(A|S) be unity for every item i. In the SHOF method, the first examinee is administered an adaptive item according to the Sympson and Hetter procedure. After the examinee has completed the test, Pi(A|S) is updated by computing the probability of item i being selected Pi(S) and administered Pi(A) as

where the K largest values of Pi(A|S) are set at unity to ensure that enough items are administered to each examinee, and K is the test length. The next examinee is then administered the updated item exposure parameters, and so on, until all examinees have completed the CAT algorithm.

Content balance control procedures not only ensure content validity but also improve item pool utility. In the MM method (Chen et al., 2003), a target percentage in each content area for a test is specified, and a cumulative probability is computed. Before an examinee takes the test, a random number is generated from a uniform distribution between 0 and 1 and is compared with the cumulative probability. If the random number is less than or equal to the cumulative probability, the administered content is selected as the highest priority to meet the content balancing requirement. By definition, the MM method always guarantees the desired content balance.

Two simulation studies were conducted to evaluate the performance of the HIRT-based CAT. Study 1 evaluated how the FI method would perform under different conditions of test length, item pool size, item response model, and factor loading. Study 2 compared the FI method with the PG and PP methods when the SHOF method was implemented for item exposure control and the MM method for content balancing, because control procedures for item exposure and content balance are widely implemented in high-stakes CAT programs.

sec.title: Simulation Study Design 1: No Practical Constraints
sec.p: The hierarchical structure consisted of three first-order latent traits and one second-order latent trait. Four major independent variables were manipulated: (a) test length—short (30 items) and long (60 items), which were consistent with the MCAT literature (Mulder & van der Linden, 2009; Riley, Dennis, & Conrad, 2010; Wang & Chen, 2004); (b) item pool size—200 items per test and 400 items per test; (c) item response model—2PLM and 3PLM; and (d) factor loadings for the three first-order latent traits—high (.9, .8, and .7, respectively) and diverse (.9, .6, and .3, respectively). As shown in the ‘Introduction’ section, factor loadings in empirical studies often fall between these two extreme conditions of high and diverse loadings.

The difficulty parameters were drawn from a uniform distribution between −3 and 3; the discrimination parameters from a normal distribution with mean 1 and variance 0.25, and truncated above 0.1; and the pseudo-guessing parameters from a uniform distribution between 0 and .3. The item parameter generation was conducted separately in the three tests. A total of 1,000 examinees were sampled from the standard normal distribution. The FI method was used for item selection, and practical constraints were not imposed.

In the CAT literature, most studies do not have replications (e.g., Barrada et al., 2008; Deng, Ansley, & Chang, 2010). This may be mainly because the overall performance of CAT algorithms across ability levels is a major concern. When the performance of the CAT algorithms at each ability level is of interest, then replications at each ability level are needed. Because the authors were interested in the overall performance of the CAT algorithms under different conditions, no replications were conducted.

sec.title: Simulation Study Design 2: Practical Constraints Imposed
sec.p: In Simulation Study 2, three item-selection methods (FI, PG, and PP) were compared. In the PG and PP methods, the acceleration parameter was set at −1, 0, 1, and 2. In the SHOF method, the maximum item exposure rate was set at .2. In the MM method, the three tests were treated as “contents,” and each test was required to constitute one third of the total length. The other settings were the same as those in Simulation Study 1. The dependent variables were the RMSD, item exposure rate, mean test overlap rate across examinees, and pool usage rate (defined as the percentages of items administered at least once). The mean test overlap rate across examinees can be computed as

where K is the test length, M is the item pool size, N is the number of examinees, and ri is the exposure rate of item i (Chen et al., 2008). The larger the mean test overlap rate, the worse the test security. It was expected that the PG and PP methods would yield higher test security, but slightly lower measurement precision than the FI method. The SHOF method and the MM method were expected to achieve their goals.

sec.title: Results From the First Simulation Study
sec.p: As shown in Table 1, the MD values were very close to zero across all conditions. The larger the item pool and the longer the test length, the closer the MD values came to zero. 2PLM yielded a smaller MD value than 3PLM. The factor loadings had little effect on the MD values. Table 2 shows the RMSD values across the conditions. As expected, the longer the test and the larger the item pool, the smaller the RMSD values. The RMSD values in 2PLM were smaller than those in 3PLM, and the RMSD values in the higher factor loading condition were smaller than those in the diverse factor loading condition. The RMSD values for the three first-order latent traits were very similar, and all of these were smaller than those for the second-order latent trait. This was because the estimation errors in the first-order latent traits accumulated and then contributed to those of the second-order latent trait.

sec.p: One might be interested in whether the correlations among the estimates for the first-order latent traits would be similar to the population correlations of .9, .8, and .7 (under the high loading condition) or .9, .6, and .3 (under the diverse loading condition). Take the 600-item pool and the 30-item test length as an example. The correlations among the estimates for the first-order latent traits were .97, .89, and .81 under the high loading condition, and .98, .70, and .42 under the diverse loading condition. The population correlations were overestimated, which was because the maximum a posteriori estimates that were used in this study were shrunken toward their prior means. The degree of shrinkage was a function of test length. If more items were administered, the overestimation would be reduced (Wu, Adams, & Wilson, 1998).

Figure 1a shows the estimated SEs for the first- and second-order latent traits under the conditions that the item pool size was 600 items, the test length was 30 items, the factor loadings were high, and the IRT model was 3PLM. It can be found that all of the estimated SEs across the ability levels were very similar and small (suggesting an equal and good measurement precision), and the three first-order latent traits had an estimated SE slightly higher than that of the second-order latent trait. Figure 1b shows those SEs under the same conditions as those in Figure 1a, except the test length was 60 items. Similar patterns were observed. A comparison of Figure 1a and 1b revealed that a longer test yielded a smaller SE. Other conditions had a similar pattern of SEs and thus are not shown. In general, the high factor loading condition had a smaller SE than the diverse condition, 2PLM had a smaller SE than 3PLM, and the item pool size had little effect on the SE. It should be noted that although a fixed-length rule was used to terminate the CAT algorithm, it can be easily adapted to incorporate a fixed-precision termination rule.

sec.title: Results From the Second Simulation Study
sec.p: Table 3 shows the maximum item exposure rates and pool usage rates in the high factor loadings and 2PLM. As expected, the maximum item exposure rates were as large as unity when the FI method was used and when no procedures for item exposure control and content balancing were implemented. When the SHOF method was imposed, the maximum item exposure rates were well controlled at the prespecified level of .2, regardless of pool sizes, test lengths, or content balancing. Moreover, the pool usage rate increased as the acceleration parameter increased in the PG and PP methods. Both the PG and PP methods successfully reduced the maximum item exposure rates and improved the pool usage rates. However, unless the SHOF method was implemented, they did not always control the maximum item exposure rates at the prespecified level of .2. The pool usage rates were not equal to 1 in the PG and PP methods because of the small sample size (1,000) relative to the item pool size. If the sample size was increased, the pool usage rates would eventually equal 1 because of the randomness incorporated into the two methods. The same conclusions could be drawn when the factor loadings were diverse or when 3PLM was used. Given this overlap, detailed results are not reported here, but they are available on request.

sec.p: Take the following case as an example of the distribution of the administered items across tests (content balancing), where the item pool had 600 items, the factor loadings were high, and the IRT model was a 3PLM. When the test length was 30 items, on average the three tests constituted 31.2%, 35.7%, and 33.1% of the test length, respectively, when the SHOF and MM methods were not implemented, and 32.0%, 33.3%, and 34.7% of the test length, respectively, when the SHOF method was implemented. When the test length was 60 items, on average the three tests constituted 32.7%, 32.8%, and 34.4% of the test length, respectively, when the SHOF and MM methods were not implemented, and 32.2%, 32.8%, and 35.0% of the test length, respectively, when the SHOF method was implemented. When the MM method was implemented, as required, each of the three tests constituted exactly one third of the test length, in both the 30 and 60 items.

Figure 2 shows the relationship between the RMSD values and the mean test overlap rates for the FI, PG, and PP methods when the factor loadings were diverse, the pool size was 600 items, the test length was 30 items, and the IRT model was a 2PLM. When item exposure and content balancing were not controlled, the FI method had the smallest RMSD value but the largest mean test overlap rate, the PP method had the smallest mean test overlap rate but the largest RMSD value, and the PG method fell between the two methods. In addition, as the acceleration parameter decreased, the RMSD value for the PG and PP methods also decreased. The difference in the RMSD values between the FI and PG methods was very small, regardless of the values of the acceleration parameter in the PG method, whereas the difference in the mean test overlap rate between the FI and PG methods increased as the acceleration parameter increased. A large acceleration parameter (e.g., 2) in the PG method appeared to be preferable to a small acceleration parameter (e.g., 0 or −1) because the former yielded slightly better test security. When the SHOF and MM methods were implemented, the FI, PP, and PG methods yielded a slightly larger RMSD value but a substantially smaller mean test overlap rate, and the PG method was superior to the FI and PP methods in maintaining measurement precision and test security. The same conclusions could be drawn when the factor loadings were high or when the IRT model was 3PLM. Thus, again, detailed results are not shown, but they are available on request.

sec.title: Discussion and Conclusion
sec.p: CAT algorithms for HIRT have been successfully developed, and their performance has been evaluated. The results of Simulation Study 1 indicate that the longer the test, the larger the item pool, and the larger the factor loadings, the better the measurement precision. Furthermore, 2PLM has better measurement precision than 3PLM. All of the results were expected and consistent with the CAT literature. Simulation Study 2 assesses the efficiency of different item-selection methods, with or without control procedures of item exposure and content balance. The results suggest that although the FI method always yields the smallest RMSD value, it has no control over item exposure, test overlap, content balance, and pool usage. The PG and PP methods, yielding a slightly larger RMSD value than the FI method, perform very satisfactorily in terms of reducing item exposure rates and mean test overlap rates, and improving pool usage. Regardless of the values of the acceleration parameter, the PG method almost always has the same measurement precision as the FI method; it also has smaller item exposure and mean test overlap, and better content balance and pool usage. Without direct control procedures for item exposure, the PG and PP methods cannot guarantee that every item will have an exposure rate below a prespecified level unless the SHOF method is implemented. In general, the PG method, along with the SHOF and MM methods, is recommended because it performed best in measurement precision, test security, pool usage, and content balance. It would be of great value to implement these algorithms in real CAT programs.

The computation time is feasible for practical CAT programs. In the simulation of the three first-order and one second-order latent traits, it took approximately 0.02 s to select an item from the item bank when the SHOF and MM methods were implemented. Whether the computation time is still feasible when there are more first-order or second-order latent traits should be carefully assessed.

Several issues were not investigated in this study and should be explored in the future. First, the simulation design was limited to three first-order latent traits and one second-order latent trait, mainly because the HIRT literature focuses on these two orders, and the parameter recovery for the third-order HIRT has not yet been investigated. In practice, more first-order and second-order latent traits may be involved. The algorithms performed fairly well in these restricted simulation conditions. Similar performance can be expected under different conditions because the algorithms do not depend on conditions. Second, a fixed-length rule was used to terminate the CAT algorithm in this study. The implementation of fixed-precision termination rules is straightforward, and their performance needs further evaluation. Third, only dichotomous items were examined in this study. However, in recent years, polytomous items have been widely used in educational and psychological tests. The development of HIRT-based CAT algorithms for polytomous items would be of interest. Fourth, although there are a great many methods for item selection, ability estimation, item exposure control, and content balancing, this study investigates only a few of them. Finally, in addition to CAT, computerized classification testing has received much attention in recent years (Thompson, 2009; Wang & Huang, 2011). The development of computerized classification testing algorithms under the HIRT model would be a valuable contribution to this field of study in the human sciences.
